column2: Fundamental unit of ecology. Has a membrane, transforms and moves energy, and alters the condition of the environment.

Results of breeding two different species and the offspring can create viable offspring (Donkey and zebra, lion and tiger)
understand how adaptations allow an organism to survive in its environment
individuals  of the same species living in a particular area
Examines variation in the number, density, and composition of individuals
distribution is the extent of th and or water within which a population lives
total number of individuals
number per unit area
number of age, gender, or genetics
Populations of species living together in a particular area.
understanding the diversity and interactions of organisms living together in the same place
One of more communities of living organisms interacting with their nonliving physical and chemical environment
Describes the storage and transfer of energy and matter
All ecosystems on earth combined by wind, water, and movement of organisms.
Examines movement of energy and chemicals over the earth's surface.

Matter and energy cannot be created or destroyed, can change form. Ecological systems can gain or lose energy. Organization of community is important. What organisms do with their energy makes them different.
an attribute of an organism (morphology or behavior)
the set of genes a organism carries, determines an organisms phenotype.
changes of genes in a population through differential survival and reproductions of individuals with certain phenotypes
individuals very in traits, traits are heritable, variation in traits causes some individuals to experience higher fitness.
autotrophs - Make their own energy
heterotr0phs - obtain energy from other organisms
Both produced and consumers (Venus Fly Trap)
Consume dead animals
Break down dead organic matter
Break down detritus into simpler elements that can be recycled
When two organisms depend on the same resource and have a neg effect on each other
two species benefit from each other
One benefits, another is not affected
Place or physical setting where an organism lives, determined by physical features
Range of abiotic and biotic condition and organism can tolerate
addresses the cause of immediate changes in individual phenotypes or interactions (How and What)
address the fitness costs and benefits of a response (Evolutionary response (Why))
Where a hypothesis is tested by altering a factor to be the cause of a phenomenon
The factor that we want to manipulate in the Study
object we want to apply manipulation
being able to reproduce a similar outcome multiple times
requirement for manipulation experiments, every experimental unit must have an equal change of being assigned to a particular treatment.
an approach to hypothesis testing that relies on natural variation in the enviornment to test a hypothesis
representations of a system with a set of equations that correspond to hypothesized relationships among system components
potential energy generated by the attractive forces and soil particles,occurs because water molecules and soil particles have electrical charges
Max num of water held by soil in gravity (Normal conditions). Gravity will cause water to drain out of soil. -.01 MPa
100% water, 0 MPa
When water is held too tightly, prevents plant from getting it, higher wilting point. -1.5 MPa
Attraction of substance to itself
Osmotic pressure of the roots of a plant compared to the rest of the soil
process which leaves can generate water potential as water evaporates from the surfaces of leaf cells.

Mechanism of water movement in pants from roots to leaves. Osmosis pushes water into roots, gradient of water from high in roots to low in leaves due to transpiration. Water moves naturally because water has high cohesion, which helps it move up the plant.
small opening in leaves, controlled by guard cells. Regulates transpiration happens. Points of entry for CO2

column1: Where would you find most stomata on the plants terrestrial vs aquatic
column2: Stomata in terrestrial plants are on bottom of leaves, prevents wilting, on top for aquatic for CO2 letting out water
packaged in photons. We see the visible spectrum - 400-700nm (violet to red)
400 nm (violet) and 700 nm (red) - photosynthetically active region
400 to 450 range abs, red and violet absorbed
Absorbs greens, reflects orange.
accessory pigments that capture light energy and pass to a.
6CO2 + 6H2O + photons -> C6H12O6+ 602. Happens in 2 steps, light reactions and Calvin cycle
Chlorophyll in thylakoids absorb photons, releases e to chain of reactions. Splits H20 molecules, forms O2, energy and hydrogen created used to create ATP and NADPH from ADP and NADP+.
Takes place in stroma of chloroplast - uses generated ATP and NADPH and takes CO2 to convert to glucose.  **C02 + RuBP -> 2g3p** in a C3 plant.
grasses, sedges. Stressful conditions, must maximize CO2 used

organisms ability to maintain constant internal conditions
The action of internal response mechanisms that restores a system to a desired state, or set point, when the system deviates from that state.
hen specific blood vessels shut off so less of an animal’s warm blood flows to cold extremities where heat would be lost. Shunting occurs at _precapillary sphincters_.
helps to conserve heat by positioning arteries that carry warm blood away from the heart alongside veins that carry chilled blood from the extremities back to the heart.
The ability of an organism to control the temp of their body
Organisms that maintain constant temperature
Organisms that can generate metabolic heat
Temperatures determined by environment
Organisms that do not have constant body temperatures.
squirrel, hybernation
tissue solute concentrations are higher than surrounding water.
tissue solute concentrations are lower than surrounding water.
mechanisms organisms use to maintain a proper solute balance.
adaptation where blood and water flow in opposite directions so that the concentration of O2 in water is always greater than the concentration in blood. (HW)
in mangroves extend above the water to absorb oxygen directly from the air!
a ratio of a physiological process rate at one temperature to the rate of that process when the temperature is 10°C cooler.
chemicals present in some animals (e.g., Arctic cod) that prevent freezing by reducing strength of hydrogen bonds or via supercooling (i.e., coating of ice seeds).
the range of temperatures in which an organism best performs.
different forms of an enzyme that catalyze a reaction. Temperatures that exceed thermal optima can be detrimental
loss of color in corals as a result of the corals expelling their symbiotic algae.
chemicals present in some animals (e.g., Arctic cod) that prevent freezing by reducing strength of hydrogen bonds or via supercooling
Temporal variation in temperature and precipitation over periods of hours or days.
Temporal typical atmospheric conditions that occur through the year, measured over many years.
be caused by factors such as climate, land topography.
variation is generated by factors such as plant structure or soil.
an attribute of organisms - behavior,morphology, or physiology. Genes interacting with environments
a situation in which a given phenotype experiences higher fitness in one environment, whereas other phenotypes experience higher fitness in other environments

ability of a singe genotype to produce multiple phenotypes, When environmental variation results in phenotypic trade-offs, natural selection will favor the evolution of phenotypic plasticity. Traits including behavior, growth, development, and reproduction can be plastic.
For an organism to alter its phenotype in an adaptive way, it must first be able to sense its environmental conditions.
which is an environmentally induced change in an individual’s physiology, can also be relatively rapid. Rapid responses are often reversible, whereas slow responses are often irreversible. Tanning.
variety of phenotypically plastic strategies for high and low competition. ex. digestive morphology.
individuals that produce both male and female gametes; individuals are able to fertilize their eggs with their own sperm (i.e., they are self-compatible).

the decrease in fitness caused by matings between close relatives due to offspring inheriting deleterious alleles from both the eggs and the sperm. Because of the cost of inbreeding depression some species wait until self-fertilization becomes the last chance for reproduction.
locations within a habitat that differ in environmental conditions from the rest of the habitats
plants root to shoots ratio. Scarce water -> higher roots:shoots ratio
producing antifreeze chemicals that control the formation of ice crystals, burrow
change the osmotic potential of body fluids by synthesizing large quantities of organic solutes.
more rapid breathing, an increase in the number of red blood cells, and increased heart rate.
seasonal movement of animals from one region to another. Response to changing environmental conditions, such as temperature or food supplies
When resources are limited and migration is not possible, storage of resources can be an adaptive strategy. Fat or food supplies for animals, nutrients and energy in roots for plants
a condition in which organisms dramatically reduce their metabolic processes
involves a partial or complete physiological shutdown in response to unfavorable conditions; common in insects. *Any time*.
individuals reduce the energetic costs of being active by lowering heart rate and decreasing body temperatures; common in mammals. *Winter*.
the shutting down of metabolic processes during the summer in response to hot or dry conditions. Well-known examples include snails, desert tortoises, and crocodiles. *During the summer*

foraging behavior in which acquired food is brought to a central place (e.g., a nest with young birds). Forages farther from the central place = greater amounts of resources, but logarithmic scale of time spent searching and food found.
foraging behavior that is influence by the presence of predators.

A predator should always eat the prey species that provides the highest amount of energy gained per unit time. If the highest energy prey is rare, the animal should include less profitable items in its diet.
the amount of time that a predator takes to consume a captured prey.
consume a varied diet because one type of food might not provide all of the necessary nutrients.
the process of solar radiation striking Earth, being converted to infrared radiation, and being absorbed and re-emitted by atmospheric gases.
the fraction of solar energy reflected by an object.
the cooling effect of reduced pressure on air as it rises higher in the atmosphere and expands.
the heating effect of increased pressure on air as it sinks toward the surface of Earth and decreases in volume.
when water vapor is converted back to liquid, water releases energy in the form of heat and warms air.
the two circulation cells of air between the equator and 30 degrees N and 30 degree S latitudes.
the area where the two Hadley cells converge and cause large amounts of precipitation.
the deflection of an object’s path due to the rotation of Earth.
large-scale water circulation pattern between continents.
compact structures consisting of long strands of DNA wound around proteins(Histones)
Regions of DNA that code for particular proteins
different forms of a particular gene.
collection of alleles from all individuals in a population.
an allele that masks the expression of the other allele.
an allele whose expression is masked by another allele; most harmful alleles are recessive.
when two alleles both contribute to the phenotype (e.g., flower color in snapdragons).
when a single trait is affected by several genes; enables phenotypes to span a range of values in a population.(eg Eye color, height)
when a single gene affects multiple traits. eg sicke cell anemia
when the expression of one gene is controlled by another gene.
when an individual has two different alleles of a particular gene.
when an individual has two identical alleles of a particular gene.
the process of making haploid gametes in which the combination of alleles that are placed into a given gamete could be any combination of those possessed by the diploid parent.
a  random change in the sequence of nucleotides in regions of DNA that controls the expression of a gene.
the reshuffling of genes that can occur as DNA is copied during meiosis and chromosomes exchange genetic material. Can hel immune system rapidly evolve
Mutations that negatively impact physiological functions are not favored by selection, but a small fraction can be beneficial.
a process that occurs when genetic variation is lost due to random variation in mating, mortality, fecundity, and inheritance.
a reduction of genetic diversity in a population due to a large reduction in population size (e.g., from loss of food).Loss in alleles
when a small number of individuals leave a large population to colonize a new area and bring with them only a small amount of genetic variation.
the process by which certain phenotypes are favored to survive and reproduce over other phenotypes.

when individuals with intermediate phenotypes have higher survival and reproductive success than those with extreme phenotypes. Occurs when the environment is relatively unchanging. Generates little evolutionary change.
when individuals with either extreme phenotype experience higher fitness than individuals with an intermediate phenotype. genetic and phenotypic variation increases.
when individuals with extreme phenotypes experience higher fitness than the average population phenotype.
the evolution of populations; affected by random processes and selection.
Selection in which humans decide which individuals will breed; breeding is done with a preconceived goal for the traits in the population (e.g., dogs, wild mustard).
favors trait combinations that provide higher fitness to an individual.

column1: How do we get random variation
column2: Random assortment, recombination, mutations, genetic drift, bottleneck, founders

column1: How do we get non-random variation
column2: Stabilizing (average genotype is good), disruptive(average genotype is bad), directional(extreme phenotype is best)
a phenomenon in which industrial activities cause habitats to become darker due to pollution; individuals possessing darker phenotypes are favored by selection.
evolution at higher levels of organization including species, genera, families, orders, and phyla.
the evolution of new species.
hypothesized patterns of relatedness among different groups such as populations, species, or genera; depict which groups evolved from other groups.
the evolution of new species through the process of geographic isolation.
the evolution of new species without geographic isolation.
a species that contains three or more sets of chromosomes; can also give rise to sympatric speciation.
the schedule of an organism’s growth, development, reproduction, and survival; represents an allocation of limited time and resources to achieve maximum reproductive success.
Long time to sexual maturity, Long life spans,Low numbers of offspring, High parental investment
Short time to sexual maturity, Short life spans, High numbers of offspring, Little parental investment
the number of offspring produced by an organism per reproductive episode.
the number of reproductive episodes an organism experiences.
the time and energy given to an offspring by its parents.
the life span of an organism.
